instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.PP3V0_G3H: What is PP3V0_G3H? PP3V0_G3H is a 3.0v power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board that gets into a S0 state, but no fan spin or image. Since I can't find the correct schematic and brd I'm using the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> one, seems to work ok with this board.

The board takes about 0.77A and CPU is getting hot, so seems to boot. I'm not getting <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> tho.
Some measurements:

<SIGNAL>PP3V0_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3V
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 1.098V
<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> = 0.6V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S0SW</SIGNAL> = 1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_T139</SIGNAL> = 5.12V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5.12V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL> = 3.31V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL> = 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> = 13.03V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0.999V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.25V
<SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4V

Those rails look fine to me, still <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> it not turning <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on.

No visible liquid damage. I kind of suspect <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, but the area around that chip looks just fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I?m pretty sure it?s not possible to have VCore but no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>...double check that. Do you get any external video?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Recheck <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal.
Strange to get complete power sequence without it...

Check for USB activity and external video.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Rechecked <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, still not present (0.0V). Tested on both <RESISTOR>R7103</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7805</RESISTOR>

Also checked <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_VCORE1</SIGNAL>/2, both are 5.12V.

No external image. Can't test USB activity since this board doesn't have actual USB-B connection, and I don't have a USB-C>USB-A convertor

I am noticing that if you leave power on for a while, and the CPU is getting really hot the fans start spinning. But no fan spin when you apply power to a cooled board

[edit]
I did find a USB-C->A convertor, but no USB activity it seems (tested with a USB drive with a flashing LED, no light at all on the USB drive)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_VCORE</SIGNAL> is not CPU Vcore. <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is Vcore. I'm assuming that is missing due to no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL>, but if the CPU is getting hot with no VCore, this is bad and probably a dead CPU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is 1.098V as stated in my first post.

So apparently it's not surposed to get <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> without <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>? Is it possible there is a line break in the <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> line, so <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is actually outputting voltage on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> to the CPU, but not to other parts of the system? Would not be easy to check I guess

[edit]
Let's say just for testing purposes I manually wire 3.3V to <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R7103</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R7805</RESISTOR>, can something go wrong? Can I break more than already is?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Is <RESISTOR>R7805</RESISTOR> good?
Even if you get VCORE, missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is "letal".
This denotes a PCH issue, as it shouldn't enable VCORE in this case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Checked <RESISTOR>R7805</RESISTOR>, is 10k as it should.

So is it certain that it's a PCH issue? This pretty much makes the board unrepairable, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get 3V at pin 1/<RESISTOR>R7805</RESISTOR>?

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is controlled by <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> in this model.
It monitors other power rails and power good signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yes, 3.3V on pin 1/<RESISTOR>R7805</RESISTOR>, but 0V on pin 2. So <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> is very likely pulling it down.

On page 74 of the schematic it seems all the required voltages are present to enable <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, even though I find this type of diagram kind of confusing, since it's not always clear what is an input or output. Would replacing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> still be a possible solution?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A S0 state, no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Should be <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, but you cannot be 100% sure.
Internal damage on SMC can cause that too.
If you can cut off the trace for <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>, you can see which chip pulls down the signal.

Reflow <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> with good flux.
Maybe bad contact for one supervised voltage...
